I'm sorry, but that spot is reserved to Azir.

Shaco's skill floor isn't high (after his rework it is even lower) but his skill ceiling is incredibly high. When you're skilled enough you can do more stuff than Azir with similar skill level.

Other than that I would place Vlad as harder than Azir.

> Other than that I would place Vlad as harder than Azir.

http://i3.kym-cdn.com/photos/images/facebook/000/993/875/084.png

Since his tank build was gutted (and thank Riot for that) he needs to build AP to be revelant thus being squishy as hell as close ranged mage with no gapclosing ability and no defensive abilities other than very long cooldown W that takes 20% of his HP anyway. 
You need to constantly flank their team, make 100% usage of your damage amp from ult, manage your health costs because heal timing ,and time your abilities properly because one little mistake will cost your life and impact (his heal won't proc in the hour of need). His abilities (besides R) are also telegraphed and kinda delayed to actually do so much damage. His laning phase is weak as hell and that can be easily abused.

Azir on the other hand despite weak early game damage was always very safe with his zoning potential, dash, range and slow, his abilities aren't delayed nor heavily telegraphed and his kit has response for every threat, every counterplay or even counterbuild enemy can pull off. He is basically hyperscalling lane bully. Unlike Vlad he can negate every response from enemy team.

I might be in error but this is how I personally see things.

Its hard for me to tell who is the hardest champion in League. I just wanted to share my opinion that Azir is overrated in this category due to number of tools in his kit (yes he is hard, but not as hard as people make him to be).

More tools translates into more room possible mechanical mastery. Saying Vlad has a high skill ceiling is kind of like saying Garen has a high skill ceiling. It takes a knowledge of the champions strengths, weaknesses, capabilities, etc. and a lot of practice with decision making to succeed with champs that don't have any mechanical demands, which gives them a higher skill ceiling then at first glance, so champs like this can be harder to play effectively than a more mechanically complex champion. (How do you play against a team of players that know you want to run straight up to them and fight them from close range?)

With champions with a lot of mechanical possibilities, the skill ceiling comes from exploiting advanced mechanical techniques. There is still a learning curve when it comes to knowing how the champ performs and making decisions based on that, and in order to get a sense of that you have to also be playing that champ to their highest mechanical limits, which is why they're seen as having higher skill ceilings. Once you reach that mechanical mastery though, the decision making element becomes less demanding because there's so much you can do with the champion, versus champs who are limited by a lack of mechanics and are wholly reliant on decision making.

On a side note, for the champion that requires the most skill without having any mechanical demands, I say it's Singed. [Just watching through this Singed guide](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-WAdszfTerM&t=19s) the kind of map awareness and judgement you need to have good strategic decisions while playing Singed makes my head hurt.

Too add onto that, the difference between Azir and Other champions is that imo, he has WAY too many tools to justify how "hard" he is too play.
Before the nerfs it was not hard to succeed as Azir.
You summoned your shoulders, Q'd and then poked down the enemy.
Run away with E if you ever get ganked. 

Nothing about Succeeding as Azir was ever really difficult (talking pre-dumpster) because he had a tool in his kit for EVERY SINGLE Situation in the game. 

There's nothing actually that hard about a champion who is prepared for everything. 

My point is that playing Azir when he's not garbage tier is not really that hard, if anything he's on par with Orianna honestly. 
However making massive outplays and utilizing EVERY tool he has is quite difficult,  but only because there is simply so much in his kit to use. Using all of it, especially in one teamfight is quite hard to manage as Azir. 

There's a significant difference between mechanical skill, and strategical skill. 
Azir has so much in his kit to justify having the highest mechanical skill floor in the game, but Strategy-wise that honor falls onto other champions like {{champion:163}} or {{champion:35}}, Their kits don't have tools that apply to every situation, so making their kits work in a way that DOES, is what makes them so deceptively hard to play.

Exactly what I'm saying. There are merits that contribute the to skill ceiling of both, but if you master a champ's mechanical demands, then their wide array of tools means that decision making becomes less critical because you can do so many things so well. But to reach the mechanical mastery to do that and practice it enough to get a feel for it is something not everyone can do, so it doesn't mean their skill ceiling isn't high.

I wasn't talking entirely on Vlad's skill ceiling, I said that he has really high skill floor. Without much knowledge about this champion and stuff you will be useless whole game long because of his atrocious laning phase and how hard it is to utilize your damage in teamfight due to telegraphed, delayed, close ranged abilities and the thing that you can be peeled off anytime and if your timing and positioning is shit you will die. All he brings to the table is unreliable damage dealt in close range.
Even in one of the patch notes if I remember correctly it was stated that Vlad is one of the hardest champions to play (if I'll find it then I will post it below).

Azir in my opinion has lower skill floor because of number of the tools and safety that isn't hard to utilize. Of course his tools, how to use them properly in any situation is hard but it says more about skill ceiling (just like in Zed's case). All you really need to contribute is make your laner feel miserable because you're lane bully and then use impossible to miss ult as disengage or in Anivia's fashion blocking the backline from fight. His damage output is also much more reliable, safer and anyone can utilize it.

Found it: http://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/news/game-updates/patch/patch-73-notes look for Vlad section.

What makes champion hard is their skill floor. As a newcomer you will be total useless garbage as Ryze, Taliyah, Vlad, Riven, Bard because how high their skill floor is. You need to play several games to at least mean something in game.
Garen (i'll ignore the fact that he is weak ATM) has really low skill floor, probably the lowest in game after Warwick's rework. Newcomers will do some meaningful actions. His skill ceiling is probably only animation cancel with Q and E.

Azir before his gutting had in my opinion medium skill floor and ridiculously high skill ceiling. There is much to learn to become better with this champion but due to being ranged with decent gapclose, tones of zoning, self peel and reliable damage he wasn't so hard to use somewhat effectively once you got used to autoattack-soldiers synergy.
With the distinction between skill ceiling and skill floor, your argument makes a lot more sense. Thanks for clarifying what you meant!

That's what I'm saying. He isn't hard because his skill floor is really low. But the things you can do with him makes his skill ceiling bonkers.

Zed has for example has medium/low skill floor, all you have to do is place your W behind you, go in with R and hit E few autos and Q and then disegange with W for your opponent to die. But here is the thing that with proper shadow placement, hitting multiple shurikens and acting as fast as possible you might actually outplay their whole team (they will miss their CC on you, you will kill maybe 2 targets etc.) while you'll safely escape. His skill ceiling is incredible.

Shaco has really low skill floor. No skillshots, long ass stealth, big damage, big presence. You might QW autoattack a bit and then execute with E and disengage with ult or Q or even both.
But your boxes placement (preparing for teamfights, for escape routes or chain CC with triangle place pattern), clone micro to make it act natural, to fool your enemies and zone your opponents after it dies in teamfight is really hard to do. You can watch some games on youtube from one of the best Shaco players: Pink Ward to see what I mean.

Meddler gave us the easy definition of both skill floor and skill ceiling:

"Skill floor: How good at a champion you need to be to start playing them somewhat effectively. Tends to be concerned with first handful of games especially (e.g. as my first game on Anivia will I feed and have no fun or be weak but make some meaningful contributions?).

Skill ceiling: How long you can keep getting meaningfully better at a champion. Tends to be concerned about players with hundreds of games (e.g. if I've played 200 games as Singed am I still learning new ways to perform better?)."
